name: politico

name: politico
text: President Trump kicked up a firestorm this weekend for ousting the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who was looking into some of his associates. But now Trump’s getting cover from a predictable source: congressional Republicans. https://t.co/suA0Or7euQ

name: politico
text:
Charles Booker’s late surge in Kentucky is threatening to prematurely end the campaign of one of the Democratic Party's top recruits today: former fighter pilot Amy McGrath.

But he's still an underdog to pull the major upset. https://t.co/8qSdWYMLsT

name: politico
text: Booker’s burst in the final stretch of the primary came after McGrath spent nearly a year running what essentially amounted to a general election campaign against Sen. Mitch McConnell https://t.co/8qSdWYMLsT

name: politico
text: If McGrath wins — most Democrats tracking the race think she remains the favorite — it will be another bitter defeat for the left wing of the party, which is also seeking victories in several House primaries  https://t.co/8qSdWYMLsT https://t.co/deJCtC20XJ

name: politico
text: If Booker manages to pull it off, it would be the first primary defeat for a candidate backed by the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee in a decade https://t.co/8qSdWYMLsT https://t.co/F1QRjy1A5K

name: politico
text: McGrath's campaign has spent more than $12 million on TV so far, compared with just $1.3 million for Booker, who did not start advertising on TV until the second week in June, according to data from Advertising Analytics https://t.co/8qSdWYMLsT

name: politico
text: A major factor creating uncertainty is voting changes because of the pandemic. The state allowed all voters to request absentee ballots but also limited in-person voting stations, including just one polling location in Jefferson County https://t.co/8qSdWYMLsT https://t.co/44fWyLVIvn

name: politico
text: Regardless of who emerges as the nominee, defeating McConnell will clearly be an uphill climb in a state that hasn’t elected a Democrat to the Senate in three decades. But the approaches would be very different https://t.co/8qSdWYMLsT

text: We have a jam-packed primary day, even if we likely won’t know the winners of hotly-contested primaries in New York and Kentucky tonight. Here’s our guide to the biggest races of the day 👇https://t.co/oyIpLnRZUt

name: politico
text: New York’s elections have entered completely uncharted waters — the primary calendar was changed, as was the method of casting and counting ballots. The winning candidates are likely to be those best able to navigate these changes. https://t.co/3mIGHm7cbW

name: politico
text:
President Trump on Tuesday insisted he was serious when he revealed earlier that he directed his administration to slow coronavirus testing in the U.S.

And his remarks today shattered the defenses of senior White House aides who argued he was just kidding https://t.co/D0xbpHldc6 https://t.co/CUuYAZNPKI

name: politico
text:
White House trade adviser Peter Navarro suggested Sunday Trump never issued such an explicit directive, saying Trump's rally remarks were “tongue in cheek.”

White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany also said it was "a comment that he made in jest” 
https://t.co/ffgLu5lKLP

name: politico
text:
More than 120,000 Americans have already died as a result of #Covid19.

Although health experts universally agree the U.S. needs more coronavirus testing, not less, Trump remained adamant in his reasoning Tuesday https://t.co/ffgLu5lKLP

name: politico
text: Trump's remarks today came roughly an hour before Dr. Anthony Fauci, the country’s top infectious disease expert, and other senior health officials within the administration were scheduled to testify before Congress about the ongoing pandemic https://t.co/ffgLu5lKLP

name: politico
text:
When asked about Trump's #Covid19 testing comments, Fauci said: "It's the opposite. We're going to be doing more testing — not less."

"To my knowledge, none of us have ever been told to slow down on testing. That just is a fact" https://t.co/snsoVtvCwm https://t.co/2IMkIF2WZA

name: politico
text: Barack Obama raised more than $4 million from 120,000 individual donors ahead of his first fundraiser for presumptive Democratic nominee Joe Biden https://t.co/t1y9gTih5T

name: politico
text: BREAKING: A prosecutor who withdrew from the Roger Stone case after DOJ leaders intervened to recommend a lighter sentence intends to testify before Congress that he was pressured to cut Stone "a break" because of his relationship with Trump https://t.co/nV49kKbyjN

name: politico
text: "What I heard — repeatedly — was that Roger Stone was being treated differently from any other defendant because of his relationship to the President," Aaron Zelinsky, one of four prosecutors who quit the case, plans to tell the House Judiciary Committee https://t.co/nV49kKbyjN

name: politico
text: "I was also told that the acting U.S. Attorney was giving Stone such unprecedentedly favorable treatment because he was 'afraid of the President,'" Zelinsky continues to say in his prepared testimony https://t.co/nV49kKbyjN

name: politico
text: Zelinsky will appear alongside antitrust prosecutor John Elias, who plans to testify that Attorney General William Barr personally ordered the Justice Department's Antitrust Division to launch politically motivated reviews of 10 cannabis mergers https://t.co/nV49kKbyjN

name: politico
text: Keeping the lights on and maintaining a comfortable temperature inside takes a lot of energy, and efforts to reduce that demand find bipartisan support — a rare bright spot in contentious debates over climate change policy https://t.co/kBcucE8vl7

name: politico
text: Energy efficiency presents a classic win-win scenario — it can lower homeowners’ utility bills and reduce pollution — but is still a difficult area to legislate https://t.co/kBcucE8vl7

name: politico
text: The need for another economic stimulus may show whether Congress can make progress on efficiency, while sidestepping the thornier issues https://t.co/kBcucE8vl7

name: politico
text: In their latest infrastructure bill, House Dems included rebates of up to $4,000 to people who renovate their homes to reduce energy use. A separate bill will establish a $500M online training program for contractors who perform efficiency retrofits https://t.co/kBcucE8vl7

name: politico
